poem:
"Mistakes of the Printing Press"

In the hasty churn of ink and paper,
Erroneous Duvaliers dance between margins,
Confounding father and son in Tropical disarray.

The moon, hefty lady of luminous lace,
is deflated, a paragraph's astronomical miscalculation.

Yet errors though they be,
to the poet's eye - unscripted beauty,
Kindling fire in the cold corner of facts.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Corrections and clarifications • An article confused the former Haitian dictator Jean-Claude “Baby Doc” Duvalier with his father, “Papa Doc” Duvalier, by misnaming him as François (No end to Haiti’s agony as gang violence spreads, 2 April, p23). • The mass of the moon is about 70 billion billion tonnes, not “70bn tonnes” as an article suggested owing to an editing error (Moon’s unique sites for exploring secrets of universe ‘being put at risk’ by". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
